A large amount of conservative thought is to deny that social problems, like racism, still exist. One of sociology’s goals is to make issues rise to the surface that conservatives would normally sweep under the rug.

I see a lot of people saying that there is a strong liberal bias in sociology. A study that demonstrates the concept of institutionalized racism is not inherently liberal, it’s what people do with that information that’s liberal. And just because sociology demonstrates concepts that liberals use to create and support their positions doesn’t mean that a liberal bias is automatically the reason why, maybe it’s simply because the facts just tend to point people towards a liberal position, and to say that that should discredit the field of sociology is inherently a flawed way of thinking because that’s making the assumption that we can’t live in a world where facts support the liberal position and that the facts have to align with a centrist point of view (or a conservative one or it should 50/50 or something like that) which is ridiculous. The field of sociology is just like any other scientific field. It has measures put in place to address bias. Obviously it’s not going to perfect (since people aren’t perfect) but neither is any other field of science is perfect (since people aren’t perfect).

gist of video
1. What is sociology ? - Sociology is study how certain pattern of behaviour are repeating , Study of interaction between individual and society , How music that we are listening are affected by people we are surrounded with .Also society is a group of having a culture and territory .
2. What it does ? It changes us according to norms present in society , we grow up learning we must shake hand , raise hand in classes and dont needed to raise hands on dining table . All the things we learnt are not positive , sometimes it might be negative .For example a street children due to its real life experiences that might is power but a child of same age might be very peaceful and show respect towards other individuals .
3. The study of society ? If you want to study society as sociologist then you need to see society through sociological perspective . Sociological perspective consists of seeing general in particular and strange in familiar . General in particular means what you are doing will be as a recurrent pattern present in society . Example : You are no marrying , then sociolgist we see it as a general trend in society to no marry and if you are listening to a music , sociologist will get to know about your age , region , eductaion . It just means tumhare habits se society ko genralize kar paa rhe hae . ANd other one strange in familiar is like see all things that happens to you as if it is happening for first time and strange to you . then you wil able to see trends and recurring patterns .
4. Sociological perspective helps in understanding society and its problems . Also Social
5. Can help in policy making which might otherwise be filled with common sense understanding of issue and solve problems of society

For this we need to closely analyse our current heirarchy of the sciences and modify it, I strongly recommend this heirarchy, Sociologists and Philosophers your views required:
1. Mathematics, Statistics, Dynamics, Geometry
2. Physics, Astronomy, Electronics, Engineering
3. Chemistry, Geology, Material Science, Physical Geography
4. Biology, Medicine, Biotechnology, Biochemistry
5. Psychiatry, Psychology, Behavioral Science, Linguistics
6. Sociology, History, Anthropology, Art and Aesthetics
7. Culturology, Human Geography, Developmental Geography, Environmental Studies
8. Ethics, Human-Economics, Research, Education
9. Administration, Law and Politics
10. Financial-Economics, Commerce and Business
The Sections 9 and 10 can be further elaborated, Section 8 might sound like, "that is what modern Philosophy all about", wrong Philosophy is something which must be linked to all of the above fields, the 8th field is the study of education system itself, both Philosophy and the group 8 deal with scope of knowledge, however philosophy of a certain group will be studied by the specific group students, but the philosophy of the whole system and "how to make research easy for all other groups?" will be the Philosophy of group 8.

Neither can be considered 'sciences' in any hard definition. Economics is the closest discipline that could call it self a 'science' but curiously chooses not to. No Economist that I've ever met has called herself a scientist. The Author says that the goal is "truth". Beware. Most Truths found in Sociology can't be tested in the fashion of physics, chemistry, or engineering. They tend to be 'working narratives' that are bent by the inclination of the researchers. Think me wrong. . . recently published that more than 70% of all Psychology Papers CANNOT be reproduced. . . er. . . that means 70% of Peer-reviewed 'truth' isn't. . .
The Author also points out the Variables she used to determine Influence. . . Class, Neighborhood, Race, Gender & Age. Really. When you get older you'll realize that the problem with most nonsense is the way the Problem is Framed. . . she's just told you something she can't defend. Example: Who likes Justin Bieber? White, Female, Young, Middle Class, East/West Coast. Or could there be a people. . . say, a few million brown & black people on two distant continents who also enjoy the Biebs?

Sociology is interesting, it makes you think about the world. But form your own truths. . . through you life's experiences. . .

Interesting that she used "Common Sense" such as White men participating in society and that owning slaves was okay. . . she says that with no sense of Irony or History. . . just lobs it out there to hang. Read some History. . . learn of the struggles of the Americans through time. . . it's a much more interesting story that 7-11 Social Sciences pop-fiction. "Common Sense" was written by a white English citizen (arrive in America in 1774), hardly an elite, known for his cussing, drinking, defaming "good citizens". . . he wrote against King George and the French King, seemed to hate Christianity. . . The crux of the problem people have with sociology, and why they consider it to be less of a science, is because it often suggests "problems" that need to be "fixed". Labeling something as a problem is based on the value structures you choose to hold, and value structures are not scientific. For example, my value structure is to maximize people's well being and the technological evolution of the planet/species. These things are contradictory in many cases, yet they are the most fundamental aspects of my value structure.

What you consider to be a moral problem will always depend on values. Essentially by definition, when you label something as a moral problem, you are not doing science. Science explains what exists, and in it's highest form explains what could exist. But it can never express what ought to exist. What ought to exist is based on morals, religion, or whatever you hold to be true, which is not scientific. True science will explain something like, E=mc^2. This tells us what exists, and what could exist, but it does not tell us what "ought to" exist. It doesn't tell us, for example, to build an atom bomb. Once you are discussing "ought to", it is no longer science. That is not to say that it's worthless. Philosophical, ethical, and moral discourse is perhaps more valuable than science. It's how we determine what to do in the world. Just don't call it science; it's something else.

To me, more leaning towards the left (just so thats clear from the start), sociology is a joke.
I personally feel like it should be considered as an element of psychology as a whole, but I hear the arguments for having it be a field as a whole.

However, the greatest flaw of this "science" is that it builds it's axioms without available proof. The only method of verification is to perform surveys, which is quite shoddy and due to random chance has high chances of being disproven later on by a different survey. There is no way to relate sociologic problems to the materialistic world in a way that e.g. a psychologist can observe the effects of some medication increasing dopamine production.
In short, sociological theories are crafted with bias in the mind of the researcher and then are proven by a method which in itself not only suffers from easily being manipulated into aligning with the theory, but is also very fragile and due to the high chance of failure can't easily be called a fact and thus used as a building block for later theories.

As an academic advisor, I often get asked about the differences between different social science courses (since, in Texas at least, students have to take at least one in addition to two history and two political science classes). Sociology is like the big umbrella for most studies, and in some ways it catches elements of each social science, but it also gets at behavior, and motivations behind that behavior in a broader manner that some social sciences cannot. Briefly, Sociology is the study of human behavior as it is influenced by (mostly) external environmental (natural and constructed) factors. Psychology is also the study of human behavior, but with a heavier focus (though not exclusively) on individual human behavior as influenced by internal factors. Economics is an examination of individual or societal behavior in relation to currency and goods. Cultural anthropology is the study of what the different cultures or societies actually are, while genetic anthropology includes an analysis of human migration and genetic connection between societies. History is the study of past human behavior from a particular societal perspective. Religion (as a social science) is the study of human responses to unexplained phenomenon and attempts to make sense of the world through non-scientific means as they developed historically. Political science is the study of specific political actions, their development and current implementation. These lines are all fluid, but the general idea is that social sciences attempt to examine societal factors and the influence these factors have or have had upon human behavior and that same society.

Sociology is the study of social behaviour or society, including its origins, development, organisation, networks, and institutions.[1][2][3][4][5] It is a social science that uses various methods of empirical investigation[6]and critical analysis[7] to develop a body of knowledge about social order, disorder, and change. Many sociologists aim to conduct research that may be applied directly to social policy and welfare, while others focus primarily on refining the theoretical understanding of social processes. Subject matter ranges from the micro-sociology level of individual agency and interaction to the macro level of systems and the social structure.[8]

The traditional focuses of sociology include social stratification, social class, social mobility, religion, secularization, law, sexuality and deviance. As all spheres of human activity are affected by the interplay between social structure and individual agency, sociology has gradually expanded its focus to further subjects, such as health, medical, military and penalinstitutions, the Internet, education, social capital and the role of social activity in the development of scientific knowledge.

The range of social scientific methods has also expanded. Social researchers draw upon a variety of qualitative and quantitative techniques. The linguistic and cultural turns of the mid-twentieth century led to increasingly interpretative, hermeneutic, and philosophic approaches towards the analysis of society. Conversely, the end of the 1990s and the beginning of 2000s have seen the rise of new analytically, mathematically and computationally rigorous techniques, such as agent-based modelling and social network analysis.[9][10]

Social research informs politicians and policy makers, educators, planners, legislators, administrators, developers, business magnates, managers, social workers, non-governmental organizations, non-profit organizations, and people interested in resolving social issues in general. There is often a great deal of crossover between social research, market research, and other statistical fields.[11]

"Just 200 years ago in the US, it was 'common sense' that only white men were capable of participating in society, it was 'common sense' that slavery was right and that women shouldn't be allowed to vote."

Citation very heavily needed here. These were never "Common Sense" ideas. Even at the time, these were controversial, these were touchy affairs.

Slavery was never, ever, ever a settled issue, and the Founding Fathers all knew that slavery was a question that would need to be addressed later. Jefferson, himself a slaveowner, struggled his entire life trying (and failing) to reconcile the words he wrote with the actions he and his peers took.

John Adams knew women were capable of guiding society as well, and certainly held his wife's opinions in high esteem.

200 years ago, people probably wouldn't have recognised the idea of "white men" at all, and it certainly wasn't a limitation on skin colour that drove who should run society, but a limitation on property ownership.

Making broad claims like these to spin a narrative of societal progress harms the study of sociology and one should be careful when doing so.

Here's another fun one: get yourself a soda or other similar drink, then try pouring it into a coffee mug or similarly "unusual" cup and drinking it out of there. Others can work to taste (coffee/tea into a wine glass, wine into a a normal water glass, etc).

I never thought I would be the first one to raise hand and say "I disagree!" at the first episode.

1:15 "A society is just a group of people who share a culture and a territory."

First of all, a society doesn't necessarily need a territory. Nomadic people and traveller minorities do not have a territory while forming their kind of society. And societies do not share the culture as a singular, but cultural aspects. These cultural aspects vary from individual to individual in the way they participate. Furthermore this definition excludes the fact that there are societies within a broader society, and that there are various cultures within a society. This definition leads to the false conclution that there is only one society with one culture in a specific area. I find it rather problematic to start with such a wide and unclear definition. Especially while talking about culture. It simply reeks of methodological nationalism.

Someone asked the genuine and important question of whether or not sociology can be discussed without it being politically charged, and I think it's a great question. I think this is a really important aspect of sociology, politics, society, etc. We have two different words, "politics" and "sociology," which I would suggest deal with the same thing, "societies" or large groups of interconnected people. My interpretation would be that "sociology" is the study* of how societies act, what they do, and how they're organized; "politics" is the field of getting a given society to act, do things, and stay organized.

So, yes, the two can be meaningfully teased apart. One is the field of description: "The American society in 2017 can be described as ___;" the other is the field of proscription: "The American society in 2017 should be described as __, and here's how we get that to be true."

-----

*Regarding "studying" in a soft science field, as someone who studied both the hardest science (Math) and the soft science of philosophy (which is the hardest of the soft sciences I WILL FIGHT YOU)... there is a question of accuracy and rigor involved in soft science studies. Bluntly, they're more subjective. However, I would suggest that they're not totally lacking in objectivity.

Imagine a poorly calibrated thermostat. It tells you the temperature, but only by measures of 10 degrees - meaning it'll tell you the difference between 90 degrees and 40 degrees, but not between 42 and 47 degrees. So, it's not "useless," but it's not great either. Now imagine one that can give 1 degree, but not 0.1 degree. Now keep imagining more and more accurate levels of measure.

Would a thermostat that's accurate to within 0.001 degree be perfect, technically speaking? No, because we can imagine a more accurate thermostat that goes to 0.00000001 degree. But it's accurate enough for me.

IMO, same with sociology, economics, political science etc. I'm not happy with where they're currently at, but it's better to have an imperfect measure than no measure at all.

For the people who disliked the video, and came here to write/read your positions:
Please just take a moment, and think about what you're doing. This crash course barely started yet, and it already has a 10% dislike ratio. Since the video was well produced and well presented, it's fairly safe to assume that most of the dislikes came from people who assumed that the course will differ with their personal beliefs. C'mon guys, be a little open-minded.

I have, I suspect, a philosophical objection to the field in general. As this video primarily enforces the ideas that sociology is scientific and the idea that the knowledge acquired from it may be used to better society, I think this may be the right place to voice this concern.
The idea that sociological knowledge can and should be used to better society is a strange one. Because it is necessarily false. I am tempted to shout freedom at the top of my lungs here (or in all caps), but the point comes across when one critically scrutinizes the use of language used, both in this video and in sociology papers in general. Let's take an example: the freedom to express affection in public for heterosexual desire vs homosexual desire. This is a subject that is in the spotlight in Norway, where a person, among other reasons, sees a problem with polls of people feeling disgusted at public displays of homosexual affection.
This, despite our gut feelings to the contrary, is not an inhibition of the liberties of gay people. The video, to show the relevance of my little digression, implies a similar flaw in sociological reasoning in general: when you go from the observation (gay people show less affection in public) to the theory (gay people are prevented from showing affection by their social location) you invariably miss out on the complexity and the principle. It might be said that actually the sociological theory is about WHY homosexual affection is limited by social location, but then you have simply said "I am not going to explain my first step, it makes sense to me".
This is a recurring problem in sociology. The observations that sociology makes are generalized in such a way that it will naturally give rise to theories that have little to no bearing on reality. The very subtle shift from "X is happening" to "Y is happening" seems intuitive, but is not justified. I would like to see this series make a genuine effort to demonstrate these leaps in logic, and perhaps it soften my harsh opinions of sociology.
Other than, there were a few quibbles which continue on the whole idea of phrasing something technically correct vs self-explained (such as the distinction between marginalized groups and power), but these are on the whole lesser. If anyone is still reading this, I'd also like to ask for a slightly slower pace, either through talking or editing, so I have time to properly consider what is being said, especially when HOW it is being said can be so very important.

In my experience, Sociology is more like an intellectual effort (sanctioned an promoted by universities, academia, governments and other institutions) that tries to understand a set of phenomena regarding human interactions. This effort is done with a commitment to the principles of rationality (you have to be logicaly coherent) and empirism (there must be some way to verify your claims). It is not a science, but an academic discipline and there is no guarantee that it is more useful than other common sense knowledge about the aforementioned phenomena.

Hey Crash Course. Really enjoy your videos and am excited to see the sociology content come out. I would like to give one piece of feedback from today's video. During the video I found it more difficult than normal to follow along. I believe this is due to the rapid pace at which the information was given, failing to allow any one piece of information to be fully emphasized. My suggestion is if possible, slow down your presentation, use emphasis on the notes you want to resonate, and perhaps use a few quick visual pop ups from thought bubble to help make some of the more abstract ideas concrete. I likes the content, but I didn't feel like there was much in the way of tonality to indicate when we were moving from one idea to the next.

Oh boy, I'm sure the comments section is going to be full of positivity and understanding about this topic, and if there is any informed criticism of sociology in general it will have sensible foundations and be made in good faith.
